topic_or_construct: Focus framing effect (question-focus on good vs. bad consequences)
measured_by: Shark–swimmer moral vignette (Carl diverts shark toward fisherman)
justification: The article introduces a “Focus (question-focus on good vs. bad consequences; Petrinovich and O'Neill [1996])” scenario and states that “This manipulation of the question-focus in terms of good or bad consequences” is used to test the effect.

measured_by: Disease-outbreak vignette comparing Program A vs. Program B
justification: Under “Prospect (prospect framed in positive vs. negative terms; Tversky and Kahneman [1981])” the paper explains that “This vignette tests a seminal effect known as the 'Asian Disease Problem', introduced by Tversky and Kahneman [1981]'.”},{

In the “Accounting (mental accounting…)” section, the authors describe a vignette where Sarah loses either a ticket or a $20 note and note that “This vignette is a moral adaptation of another seminal finding by Tversky and Kahneman [1981] and Thaler [1985].”

The “Perspective (actor vs. observer perspective…)” vignette is said to “test the finding… that professional philosophers are equally susceptible to actor-observer bias in moral scenarios as laypeople.”

measured_by: Speed-train trolley-style scenario with three options including a dominated decoy
justification: In the “Decoy (decoy effect; Huber et al. [1982])” section the authors state, “This vignette tests the 'decoy effect', one of the best-known human violations of rational choice.”
